Context:
The three-year advanced diploma program is called Game – Programming (Online). Students attending in January (winter term) are required to attend classes during the summer months (May to August). The technology requirements include a personal computer with 8 GB RAM minimum (16 GB recommended), 256 GB SSD Hard Drive (500+ GB is optimal), approx. 100 GBs of hard disk space for required software, Quad-core i7 2.5GHz or better processor, a video card with 4GB RAM and supporting OpenGL 3.2+ and DirectX 11/12, and a webcam.

Graduates can work in various areas of the digital game industry such as software or hardware development, publisher, ISP and game portal development and maintenance, website development, distribution middleware and tool provider, production servicer, and content/IP owner. In 2015, Canada's video game industry contributed over $3 billion to the Canadian economy and provided 20,400 full-time equivalent jobs, with a significant number of studios located in Quebec (29.4%), British Columbia (27.1%), and Ontario (22.9%). Graduates have the opportunity to apply for further study in BSc (Honours) Computer Games Design.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Game – Programming Program (Online) T193 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The University of Gloucestershire offers a BSc (Honours) Computer Games Design program with level 6 entry. The following is the curriculum plan for the Computer Games Design degree:

Semester 1:
- Introduction to Programming (GAME 1001)
- Game Fundamentals I (GAME 1007)
- Game Production I (GAME 1005)
- Personal Finance (GSSC 1027)
- Math for Game Development (MATH 1180)
- Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000)

Semester 2:
- Advanced Programming (GAME 1011)
- Game Fundamentals II (GAME 1017)
- Artificial Intelligence (GAME 1014)
- Linear Algebra and Geometry (MATH 1107)
- General Education Elective (GNED)

Semester 3:
- Game Production III (GAME 2020)
- Data Structures & Algorithms (GAME 2001)
- Game Physics (GAME 2005)
- 3D Graphics Programming (GAME 2012)
- Game Engines I (GAME 2013)
- General Education Elective (GNED)

Semester 4:
- Game Production IV (GAME 2030)
- Advanced Topics in Programming Languages (GAME 2031)
- Advanced Graphics Programming (GAME 3111)
- Physics Engines (GAME 3002)
- Game Engines II (GAME 2023)
- Professional Workplace Competencies (COMP 2148)

Semester 5:
- Game Production V (GAME 3020)
- Mobile Game Development I (GAME 2014)
- Console Game Development I (GAME 3003)
- Multiplayer Systems (GAME 3110)
- Game Engines III (GAME 3023)
- Game Engine Development I (GAME 3121)

Semester 6:
- Game Production VI (GAME 3030)
- Mobile Game Development II (GAME 3004)
- Game Portfolio Development (GAME 3011)
- Game Engine Development II (GAME 3015)
- Game Engines IV (GAME 3033)
- Console Game Development II (GAME 3112)

Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000, but this course does not count towards graduation requirements and students will be charged for it.

Context:
Program Name: Game – Programming (T163), Game – Art advanced diploma program (G119)
Program Location: George Brown College
Website for more information: georgebrown.ca/assessment, georgebrown.ca/Game-Programming, georgebrown.ca/Game-Art
Program Learning Outcomes:
- Analyze the differences in game genres to develop games that meet specific market needs.
- Analyze the history of video games and compare various approaches to game development.
- Support game development by identifying and relating concepts from programming, design, and art industries.
- Contribute as an individual and team member to complete a game development project.
- Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development in the games industry.
- Comply with relevant statutes, regulations, legislation, industry standards, and codes of ethics.
Domestic Tuition (first two semesters): $3,956.00
Additional Costs: Not specified in the text
Financial Assistance: Approved for OSAP funding
Admission Requirements: Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Game – Programming Program (Online) T193 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The George Brown College offers a Game – Programming program (T163). Mature students who are 19 years of age or older and do not have an OSSD can take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math, or consider upgrading to achieve the required credits. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. The Computer Technology department is located at 3 Lower Jarvis St., Room 260, with phone numbers 416-415-5000, ext. 4287 or 3129 and email addresses computertechnology@georgebrown.ca or game@georgebrown.ca. The office hours are Monday – Friday: 9 a.m. – 4 p.m. The program coordinator's name is Alexander Richard, and their contact details are 416-415-5000, ext. 4232 and arichard6@georgebrown.ca. Classes for the Game – Programming program take place at the Casa Loma and St. James Campuses. Potential applicants can attend an information session or campus tour to learn more about George Brown College and the program, or explore the virtual tour. Related programs include Game – Art (G119) and Computer Programming and Analysis (T177). Interested individuals can book a campus tour or information session on the college's website.

Extracted Information:
- George Brown College offers a Game – Programming program (T163).
- Mature students should consider taking the Admissions Assessment for English and Math, or upgrading to achieve required credits.
- Domestic students apply through Ontario Colleges.
- Computer Technology department contact details: 3 Lower Jarvis St., Room 260, 416-415-5000, ext. 4287 or 3129, computertechnology@georgebrown.ca or game@georgebrown.ca, Monday – Friday: 9 a.m. – 4 p.m., Alexander Richard (Program Coordinator), 416-415-5000, ext. 4232, arichard6@georgebrown.ca.
- Classes for the Game – Programming program take place at Casa Loma and St. James Campuses.
- Related programs: Game – Art (G119), Computer Programming and Analysis (T177).
- Interested individuals can book a campus tour or information session on George Brown College's website.
